elements.content: A two-dimensional manganese-octacyanoniobate based magnet, MnII 3[NbIV(CN)8]2(4-aminopyridine)10(4-aminopyridinium)2·12H2O, was prepared. This compound shows a spin-flip transition with a critical magnetic field value of ca. 200 Oe, which originates from metamagnetism. In addition, an impedance measurement indicates that this compound is a super-ionic conductor with 4.6 × 10–4 S cm–1. The observed super-ionic conductivity is explained by the proton conduction (so-called the Grotthuss mechanism) through the hydrogen-bonding network, i.e., Lewis acidity of the Mn ion accelerates the deprotonation of the ligand water molecules, and then the released proton propagates via ligand water molecules, noncoordinated water molecules, and 4-aminopyridinium cations.
elements.clean_text: A two-dimensional manganese-octacyanoniobate based magnet, MnII 3[NbIV(CN)8]2(4-aminopyridine)10(4-aminopyridinium)2⋅12H2O, was prepared. This compound shows a spin-flip transition with a critical magnetic field value of ca. 200 Oe, which originates from metamagnetism. In addition, an impedance measurement indicates that this compound is a super-ionic conductor with 4.6 × 10-4 S cm-1. The observed super-ionic conductivity is explained by the proton conduction (so-called the Grotthuss mechanism) through the hydrogen-bonding network, i.e., Lewis acidity of the Mn ion accelerates the deprotonation of the ligand water molecules, and then the released proton propagates via ligand water molecules, noncoordinated water molecules, and 4-aminopyridinium cations.

elements.content: A two-dimensional manganese-octacyanoniobate based magnet, MnII 3[NbIV(CN)8]2(4-aminopyridine)10(4-aminopyridinium)2·12H2O, was prepared. This compound shows a coexistence of metamagnetism and super-ionic conductivity. The observed super-ionic conductivity is explained by the proton conduction (so-called the Grotthuss mechanism) through the hydrogen-bonding network of ligand water molecules, noncoordinated water molecules, and 4-aminopyridinium cations.
elements.clean_text: A two-dimensional manganese-octacyanoniobate based magnet, MnII 3[NbIV(CN)8]2(4-aminopyridine)10(4-aminopyridinium)2⋅12H2O, was prepared. This compound shows a coexistence of metamagnetism and super-ionic conductivity. The observed super-ionic conductivity is explained by the proton conduction (so-called the Grotthuss mechanism) through the hydrogen-bonding network of ligand water molecules, noncoordinated water molecules, and 4-aminopyridinium cations.

elements.content: Multifunctional magnetic materials are extensively studied in the fields of chemistry and materials science. Especially, the synthesis of magnetic materials having electric functionality is an attractive issue. For instance, the coexistent system between ferromagnetism and ferroelectricity is aggressively studied in various condensed matters. In addition to ferroelectricity, ion-conductivity is also a fascinating electric functionality. However, conventional magnetic materials composed of metal alloy or metal oxide do not show ion-conductive properties. In very recent years, ion-conductive magnetic materials have been realized with metal oxalate-based magnets and hexacyanometalate-based magnets. Furthermore, vanadium-hexacyanochromate-based magnet exhibits an interference effect between proton conductivity and magnetic phase transition. From this angle, cyanometalate-based magnets are useful systems for demonstrating ion-conductive magnetism.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Multifunctional magnetic materials are extensively studied in the fields of chemistry and materials science. Especially, the synthesis of magnetic materials having electric functionality is an attractive issue. For instance, the coexistent system between ferromagnetism and ferroelectricity is aggressively studied in various condensed matters. In addition to ferroelectricity, ion-conductivity is also a fascinating electric functionality. However, conventional magnetic materials composed of metal alloy or metal oxide do not show ion-conductive properties. In very recent years, ion-conductive magnetic materials have been realized with metal oxalate-based magnets and hexacyanometalate-based magnets. Furthermore, vanadium-hexacyanochromate-based magnet exhibits an interference effect between proton conductivity and magnetic phase transition. From this angle, cyanometalate-based magnets are useful systems for demonstrating ion-conductive magnetism.

elements.content: Cyanometalate-based magnets have been aggressively studied from viewpoints of magnetic multifunctionalities, such as photoinduced magnetism and chemical stimuli-induced magnetism. Among them, octacyanometalate-based magnets are promising systems because of their structural flexibility. In addition, octacyanometalate-based magnets can incorporate organic molecules as coordinating ligands or noncoordinating molecules in the crystal. In this work, we prepared a two-dimensional (2D) manganese-octacyanoniobate based magnet, MnII 3[NbIV(CN)8]2(4-NH2py)10(4-NH2pyH+)2·12H2O (4-NH2py = 4-aminopyridine; 4-NH2pyH+ = 4-aminopyridinium), which includes noncoordinated 4-aminopyridinium cations in the interstitial sites of the lattice. This compound shows a coexistence of metamagnetism and super-ionic conductivity.
elements.clean_text: Cyanometalate-based magnets have been aggressively studied from viewpoints of magnetic multifunctionalities, such as photoinduced magnetism and chemical stimuli-induced magnetism. Among them, octacyanometalate-based magnets are promising systems because of their structural flexibility. In addition, octacyanometalate-based magnets can incorporate organic molecules as coordinating ligands or noncoordinating molecules in the crystal. In this work, we prepared a two-dimensional (2D) manganese-octacyanoniobate based magnet, MnII 3[NbIV(CN)8]2(4-NH2py)10(4-NH2pyH+)2⋅12H2O (4-NH2py = 4-aminopyridine; 4-NH2pyH+ = 4-aminopyridinium), which includes noncoordinated 4-aminopyridinium cations in the interstitial sites of the lattice. This compound shows a coexistence of metamagnetism and super-ionic conductivity.

elements.content: The target compound was prepared by the reaction of an aqueous solution of K4[NbIV(CN)8]·2H2O (0.1 mmol, 3.3 mmol dm–3) with a mixed aqueous solution of MnIICl2·4H2O (0.2 mmol, 6.7 mmol dm–3) and 4-aminopyridine (4 mmol, 130 mmol dm–3) using a slow diffusion method. Yellow crystals were obtained by filtering and washing with water. Elemental analyses confirmed that the formula of the obtained compound was Mn3[Nb(CN)8]2(4-aminopyridine)10(4-aminopyridinium)2·12H2O. Calculated: Mn, 7.8; Nb, 8.8; C, 43.2; H, 4.7; N, 26.5%. Found: Mn, 7.7; Nb, 8.7; C, 42.7; H, 4.7; N, 26.4%. The infrared (IR) spectrum showed CN stretching peaks at 2144, 2133, 2120, and 2114 cm–1.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Synthesis

The target compound was prepared by the reaction of an aqueous solution of K4[NbIV(CN)8]⋅2H2O (0.1 mmol, 3.3 mmol dm-3) with a mixed aqueous solution of MnIICl2⋅4H2O (0.2 mmol, 6.7 mmol dm-3) and 4-aminopyridine (4 mmol, 130 mmol dm-3) using a slow diffusion method. Yellow crystals were obtained by filtering and washing with water. Elemental analyses confirmed that the formula of the obtained compound was Mn3[Nb(CN)8]2(4-aminopyridine)10(4-aminopyridinium)2⋅12H2O. Calculated: Mn, 7.8; Nb, 8.8; C, 43.2; H, 4.7; N, 26.5%. Found: Mn, 7.7; Nb, 8.7; C, 42.7; H, 4.7; N, 26.4%. The infrared (IR) spectrum showed CN stretching peaks at 2144, 2133, 2120, and 2114 cm-1.

elements.content: Elemental analyses of Mn and Nb were performed by Agilent 7700 inductively coupled plasma mass spectroscopy, while those of C, H, and N were conducted using standard microanalytical methods. X-ray structural analysis was performed on a Rigaku RAXIS RAPID imaging plate area detector with graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation. The structure was solved by a direct method and refined by a full-matrix least-squares technique using SHELXL-97. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The hydrogen atoms of 4-aminopyridine, 4-aminopyridinium on aromatic ring, and ligand water molecules were refined using the riding model, while those of noncoordinated water molecules and amino group of 4-aminopyridinium were not included in the refinement. The calculation was performed using the CrystalStructure crystallographic software package. Crystallographic data have been deposited with Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre as supplementary publication No. CCDC-916575. IR spectra were recorded with a JASCO FT-IR4100 spectrometer in the 4000–400 cm–1 region. Magnetic measurements were performed using a Quantum Design MPMS superconducting quantum interference device (SQUID) magnetometer. Impedance measurements were carried out by a four-terminal pair method with an Agilent 4294A precision impedance analyzer from the 40 Hz to 110 MHz frequency range. For the impedance measurement, the powdered sample was compressed into a pellet with a 7 mm diameter and 0.10 mm thickness using a sample holder between two steel electrodes. Powder X-ray diffraction measurements were conducted on a Rigaku Ultima IV with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å) within the range of 10° ≤ 2θ ≤ 60°. Thermogravimetric (TG) measurement was carried out by Rigaku Thermo Plus TG8120.
elements.clean_text:
Measurements

Elemental analyses of Mn and Nb were performed by Agilent 7700 inductively coupled plasma mass spectroscopy, while those of C, H, and N were conducted using standard microanalytical methods. X-ray structural analysis was performed on a Rigaku RAXIS RAPID imaging plate area detector with graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation. The structure was solved by a direct method and refined by a full-matrix least-squares technique using SHELXL-97. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The hydrogen atoms of 4-aminopyridine, 4-aminopyridinium on aromatic ring, and ligand water molecules were refined using the riding model, while those of noncoordinated water molecules and amino group of 4-aminopyridinium were not included in the refinement. The calculation was performed using the CrystalStructure crystallographic software package. Crystallographic data have been deposited with Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre as supplementary publication No. CCDC-916575. IR spectra were recorded with a JASCO FT-IR4100 spectrometer in the 4000-400 cm-1 region. Magnetic measurements were performed using a Quantum Design MPMS superconducting quantum interference device (SQUID) magnetometer. Impedance measurements were carried out by a four-terminal pair method with an Agilent 4294A precision impedance analyzer from the 40 Hz to 110 MHz frequency range. For the impedance measurement, the powdered sample was compressed into a pellet with a 7 mm diameter and 0.10 mm thickness using a sample holder between two steel electrodes. Powder X-ray diffraction measurements were conducted on a Rigaku Ultima IV with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å) within the range of 10° ≤ 2θ ≤ 60°. Thermogravimetric (TG) measurement was carried out by Rigaku Thermo Plus TG8120.

elements.content: Single crystal X-ray structural analysis shows that the present compound has a monoclinic crystal system in the C2/c space group with a = 19.1498(6), b = 17.7070(4), c = 29.3088(7), and β = 103.2520(10)° (Table ; Figure S1 and Tables S1–S2, ). The asymmetric unit is composed of a [NbIV(CN)8]4– anion, a [MnII(4-NH2py)4]2+ cation, half of [MnII(4-NH2py)2(H2O)2]2+ cation, five noncoordinated (zeolitic) water molecules, and a noncoordinated 4-NH2pyH+ cation (Figure a). The two types of Mn sites (Mn1, Mn2) have six-coordinate pseudo-octahedron geometry. The Mn1 site is coordinated by two cyanide nitrogen atoms in apical positions and four pyridyl nitrogen atoms of 4-NH2py in equatorial positions, while the Mn2 site is coordinated by two cyanide nitrogen atoms, two pyridyl nitrogen atoms of 4-NH2py, and two oxygen atoms of ligand water molecules. The bond distances between Mn1 and cyanide nitrogen atoms are 2.18 and 2.20 Å, whereas those between Mn1 and pyridyl nitrogen atoms of 4-NH2py range from 2.27 to 2.31 Å. The Mn2–N(cyanide), Mn2–N(pyridyl), and Mn2–O distances are 2.23, 2.22, and 2.26 Å, respectively. The Mn–N–C angles are 168.7° and 175.9° for Mn1 and 160.2° for Mn2. The coordination geometry of the Nb site is square-antiprism. The three CN groups of [Nb(CN)8] bridge two Mn1 sites and one Mn2 site, whereas the other five CN groups are terminal. The terminal CN groups form hydrogen-bonds with O atoms of zeolitic water molecules toward three directions. The bond distances between Nb and cyanide carbon atoms range from 2.23 to 2.27 Å. The Nb–N–C angles are between 177.0° and 179.3°. The Mn–NC–Nb moiety forms a 2D coordination network structure parallel to (101̅) crystallographic plane with an interlayer distance of 8.8 Å (Figure b). The 2D layer is constructed with cyano-bridged Mn6Nb6 dodecanuclear hexagonal grids, and two noncoordinated 4-aminopyridinium cations are placed inside the hexagonal grid (Figure c). The noncoordinated water molecules are located inside and between the layers. In the crystal, 1D infinite hydrogen-bonding networks are constructed with O(water)–O(water), O(water)–N(4-aminopyridinium), and O(water)–N(terminal CN group) with the distance between 2.7 and 3.2 Å along [11̅0] and [1̅10] crystallographic directions, which penetrate the 2D network structure (Table S3, ). From the comparison of single crystal analysis with XRD data, the crushed sample, which are used in IR, SQUID, and impedance measurements, have the same crystal structure (Table S4 and Figures S2 and S3, ). The TG measurement shows that this crystal is stable at least up to 330 K (Figure S4, ).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Crystal Structure

Single crystal X-ray structural analysis shows that the present compound has a monoclinic crystal system in the C2/c space group with a = 19.1498(6), b = 17.7070(4), c = 29.3088(7), and β = 103.2520(10)° (Table ; Figure S1 and Tables S1-S2, ). The asymmetric unit is composed of a [NbIV(CN)8]4- anion, a [MnII(4-NH2py)4]2+ cation, half of [MnII(4-NH2py)2(H2O)2]2+ cation, five noncoordinated (zeolitic) water molecules, and a noncoordinated 4-NH2pyH+ cation (Figure a). The two types of Mn sites (Mn1, Mn2) have six-coordinate pseudo-octahedron geometry. The Mn1 site is coordinated by two cyanide nitrogen atoms in apical positions and four pyridyl nitrogen atoms of 4-NH2py in equatorial positions, while the Mn2 site is coordinated by two cyanide nitrogen atoms, two pyridyl nitrogen atoms of 4-NH2py, and two oxygen atoms of ligand water molecules. The bond distances between Mn1 and cyanide nitrogen atoms are 2.18 and 2.20 Å, whereas those between Mn1 and pyridyl nitrogen atoms of 4-NH2py range from 2.27 to 2.31 Å. The Mn2-N(cyanide), Mn2-N(pyridyl), and Mn2-O distances are 2.23, 2.22, and 2.26 Å, respectively. The Mn-N-C angles are 168.7° and 175.9° for Mn1 and 160.2° for Mn2. The coordination geometry of the Nb site is square-antiprism. The three CN groups of [Nb(CN)8] bridge two Mn1 sites and one Mn2 site, whereas the other five CN groups are terminal. The terminal CN groups form hydrogen-bonds with O atoms of zeolitic water molecules toward three directions. The bond distances between Nb and cyanide carbon atoms range from 2.23 to 2.27 Å. The Nb-N-C angles are between 177.0° and 179.3°. The Mn-NC-Nb moiety forms a 2D coordination network structure parallel to (101̅) crystallographic plane with an interlayer distance of 8.8 Å (Figure b). The 2D layer is constructed with cyano-bridged Mn6Nb6 dodecanuclear hexagonal grids, and two noncoordinated 4-aminopyridinium cations are placed inside the hexagonal grid (Figure c). The noncoordinated water molecules are located inside and between the layers. In the crystal, 1D infinite hydrogen-bonding networks are constructed with O(water)-O(water), O(water)-N(4-aminopyridinium), and O(water)-N(terminal CN group) with the distance between 2.7 and 3.2 Å along [11̅0] and [1̅10] crystallographic directions, which penetrate the 2D network structure (Table S3, ). From the comparison of single crystal analysis with XRD data, the crushed sample, which are used in IR, SQUID, and impedance measurements, have the same crystal structure (Table S4 and Figures S2 and S3, ). The TG measurement shows that this crystal is stable at least up to 330 K (Figure S4, ).

Crystal structure of MnII 3[NbIV(CN)8]2(4-aminopyridine)10(4-aminopyridinium)2·12H2O. (a) Coordination environment of Mn and Nb sites. Pyridyl nitrogen atom of noncoordinated 4-aminopyridine is protonated (4-NH2pyH+). (b) Crystal structure viewed along the b axis. Mn–NC–Nb moiety forms a 2D layered structure, and 4-NH2pyH+ is located inside the layer. (c) View of the layer structure. Red, green, gray, cyan, light blue, and blue balls represent Mn, Nb, C, pyridinium N, other N, and O atoms, respectively. Ligand water molecules and zeolitic water molecules are represented as O(L) and O(Z), respectively. H atoms are omitted for clarity.

Mn-NC-Nb moiety forms a 2D layered structure, and 4-NH2pyH+ is located inside the layer. (c) View of the layer structure. Red, green, gray, cyan, light blue, and blue balls represent Mn, Nb, C, pyridinium N, other N, and O atoms, respectively. Ligand water molecules and zeolitic water molecules are represented as O(L) and O(Z), respectively. H atoms are omitted for clarity.

elements.content: In the field cooled magnetization (FCM) curve of the present compound at 100 Oe, the magnetization value increases below 20 K, but suddenly decreases below 9 K (Figure a). The magnetization vs temperature curve in various external magnetic fields exhibits a sudden decrease in magnetization under the external magnetic fields from 100 to 400 Oe. However, the magnetization value monotonously increases under the external magnetic fields above 500 Oe (Figure b). The initial magnetization curve shows a spin-flip transition with a critical magnetic field value of ca. 200 Oe (Figure a). The magnetization value at 5 T was 12.3 μB, which agrees well with the calculated saturation magnetization value of 13.0 μB for the ferrimagnetic ordering between MnII (S = 5/2) and NbIV (S = 1/2) for the given formula (Figure b).
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Properties

In the field cooled magnetization (FCM) curve of the present compound at 100 Oe, the magnetization value increases below 20 K, but suddenly decreases below 9 K (Figure a). The magnetization vs temperature curve in various external magnetic fields exhibits a sudden decrease in magnetization under the external magnetic fields from 100 to 400 Oe. However, the magnetization value monotonously increases under the external magnetic fields above 500 Oe (Figure b). The initial magnetization curve shows a spin-flip transition with a critical magnetic field value of ca. 200 Oe (Figure a). The magnetization value at 5 T was 12.3 μB, which agrees well with the calculated saturation magnetization value of 13.0 μB for the ferrimagnetic ordering between MnII (S = 5/2) and NbIV (S = 1/2) for the given formula (Figure b).

elements.content: Magnetization vs temperature plots. (a) Field cooled magnetization (FCM) curve under 100 Oe (red), zero-field-cooled magnetization curve (blue), and remnant magnetization (RM) curve (black). (b) FCM curves under 100 Oe (red), 200 Oe (orange), 300 Oe (green), 400 Oe (light green), 500 Oe (light blue), 700 Oe (blue), and 1000 Oe (black).
elements.clean_text: 2  Magnetization vs temperature plots. (a) Field cooled magnetization (FCM) curve under 100 Oe (red), zero-field-cooled magnetization curve (blue), and remnant magnetization (RM) curve (black). (b) FCM curves under 100 Oe (red), 200 Oe (orange), 300 Oe (green), 400 Oe (light green), 500 Oe (light blue), 700 Oe (blue), and 1000 Oe (black).

elements.content: (a) Initial magnetization curve below 1000 Oe. (b) Magnetization vs external magnetic field curve at 2 K. Solid lines are guides to the eye.
elements.clean_text: 3  (a) Initial magnetization curve below 1000 Oe. (b) Magnetization vs external magnetic field curve at 2 K. Solid lines are guides to the eye.

elements.content: The observed anomalous FCM curve and spin-flip behavior suggests that this compound is a metamagnet. That is, as the temperature decreases in a low external magnetic field (below 400 Oe), the magnetic ordering of Mn and Nb sites begins below 20 K, while the magnetic moments in each layer, which have ferrimagnetic ordering between MnII(S = 5/2) and NbIV(S = 1/2), are antiparallel below 9 K, resulting in exhibiting antiferromagnetism. In contrast, at a high external magnetic field (above 500 Oe), magnetic moments of the layers order in a parallel manner described with the thick arrows in Figure .
elements.clean_text: The observed anomalous FCM curve and spin-flip behavior suggests that this compound is a metamagnet. That is, as the temperature decreases in a low external magnetic field (below 400 Oe), the magnetic ordering of Mn and Nb sites begins below 20 K, while the magnetic moments in each layer, which have ferrimagnetic ordering between MnII(S = 5/2) and NbIV(S = 1/2), are antiparallel below 9 K, resulting in exhibiting antiferromagnetism. In contrast, at a high external magnetic field (above 500 Oe), magnetic moments of the layers order in a parallel manner described with the thick arrows in Figure .

elements.content: Schematic illustration of a spin-flip transition. Left figure represents the antiparallel configuration under low external magnetic field. Right figure represents the parallel configuration under high external magnetic field. The small black arrows indicate the magnetic moment on Nb.
elements.clean_text: 4  Schematic illustration of a spin-flip transition. Left figure represents the antiparallel configuration under low external magnetic field. Right figure represents the parallel configuration under high external magnetic field. The small black arrows indicate the magnetic moment on Nb.

elements.content: The ionic conductivity (σ) of this compound is measured by impedance technique. Figure a shows the real (Z′) and imaginary (Z″) parts of the complex-plane impedance data from 295 to 322 K. In the present experiment, the Cole–Cole plot was well fitted by a single half-circle, indicating that the observed conductivity is attributed to the material itself. The circular arc fitting indicates that the σ value is 1.0 × 10–4 S cm–1 at 295 K at 100% RH. As the temperature increases, the σ value increases to 4.6 × 10–4 S cm–1 at 322 K. The activation energy (E a) of the ionic conductivity is understood by the Grotthuss mechanism, which takes into account the hopping of an ion (in the present case, proton from the Lewis acid sites), which obeys the following equation, σT = σ0exp(−E a/kT), where k is the Boltzmann constant. In Figure b, the ln(σT) value varies linearly with T –1, indicating that the E a value of ionic conductivity is 0.48 eV. The thermal stability of the sample for impedance measurement was confirmed by the reproducibility of the data at 295 K after cooling (Figure S5, ). The σ value clearly depends on the humidity from 1.0 × 10–4 S cm–1 (100% RH) to 3.2 × 10–8 S cm–1 (45% RH) at 300 K, indicating that the high conductivity is attributed to proton conduction. The observed σ value of 4.6 × 10–4 S cm–1 is sufficient for a super-ionic conductor (σ > 10–4 S cm–1). The present compound has a hydrogen-bonding network, which includes ligand water molecules, noncoordinated water molecules, and 4-aminopyridinium cations. The mechanism of the proton conduction is explained by the Grotthuss mechanism; Lewis acidity of Mn ion accelerates the deprotonation from the ligand water molecules, and then the released proton propagates through hydrogen-bonding network of ligand water molecules, noncoordinated water molecules, and 4-aminopyridinium cation (Figure ).
elements.clean_text:
Ionic Conductivity

The ionic conductivity (σ) of this compound is measured by impedance technique. Figure a shows the real (Z') and imaginary (Z") parts of the complex-plane impedance data from 295 to 322 K. In the present experiment, the Cole-Cole plot was well fitted by a single half-circle, indicating that the observed conductivity is attributed to the material itself. The circular arc fitting indicates that the σ value is 1.0 × 10-4 S cm-1 at 295 K at 100% RH. As the temperature increases, the σ value increases to 4.6 × 10-4 S cm-1 at 322 K. The activation energy (E a) of the ionic conductivity is understood by the Grotthuss mechanism, which takes into account the hopping of an ion (in the present case, proton from the Lewis acid sites), which obeys the following equation, σT = σ0exp(-E a/kT), where k is the Boltzmann constant. In Figure b, the ln(σT) value varies linearly with T -1, indicating that the E a value of ionic conductivity is 0.48 eV. The thermal stability of the sample for impedance measurement was confirmed by the reproducibility of the data at 295 K after cooling (Figure S5, ). The σ value clearly depends on the humidity from 1.0 × 10-4 S cm-1 (100% RH) to 3.2 × 10-8 S cm-1 (45% RH) at 300 K, indicating that the high conductivity is attributed to proton conduction. The observed σ value of 4.6 × 10-4 S cm-1 is sufficient for a super-ionic conductor (σ > 10-4 S cm-1). The present compound has a hydrogen-bonding network, which includes ligand water molecules, noncoordinated water molecules, and 4-aminopyridinium cations. The mechanism of the proton conduction is explained by the Grotthuss mechanism; Lewis acidity of Mn ion accelerates the deprotonation from the ligand water molecules, and then the released proton propagates through hydrogen-bonding network of ligand water molecules, noncoordinated water molecules, and 4-aminopyridinium cation (Figure ).

elements.content: (a) Real (Z ′) and imaginary (Z ″) parts of the complex-plane impedance at 100% RH from 295 to 322 K. Solid lines represent the circular arc fitting. (b) ln(σT) vs T –1 plots at 100% RH. Solid line represents the result of linear fitting.
elements.clean_text: 5  (a) Real (Z ') and imaginary (Z ") parts of the complex-plane impedance at 100% RH from 295 to 322 K. Solid lines represent the circular arc fitting. (b) ln(σT) vs T -1 plots at 100% RH. Solid line represents the result of linear fitting.

elements.content: Schematic proton conduction pathways through the hydrogen-bonding network. Dotted lines and solid lines represent hydrogen-bond and disorder, respectively.
elements.clean_text: 6  Schematic proton conduction pathways through the hydrogen-bonding network. Dotted lines and solid lines represent hydrogen-bond and disorder, respectively.

elements.content: In this paper, we demonstrate that super-ionic conductivity and metamagnetism coexist in a 2D manganese-octacyanoniobate-based magnet, MnII 3[NbIV(CN)8]2(4-aminopyridine)10(4-aminopyridinium)2·12H2O. The super-ionic conductivity is caused by proton conduction based on the Grotthuss mechanism. In the present material, the 4-aminopyridinium cation is incorporated into the flexible octacyano-bridged magnetic framework and plays an important role in the formation of the hydrogen-bonding network, which leads to the observation of super-ionic conductivity. We are attempting to prepare large single crystals to measure the anisotropic conductivity.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In this paper, we demonstrate that super-ionic conductivity and metamagnetism coexist in a 2D manganese-octacyanoniobate-based magnet, MnII 3[NbIV(CN)8]2(4-aminopyridine)10(4-aminopyridinium)2⋅12H2O. The super-ionic conductivity is caused by proton conduction based on the Grotthuss mechanism. In the present material, the 4-aminopyridinium cation is incorporated into the flexible octacyano-bridged magnetic framework and plays an important role in the formation of the hydrogen-bonding network, which leads to the observation of super-ionic conductivity. We are attempting to prepare large single crystals to measure the anisotropic conductivity.

elements.content:
The manuscript was written through contributions of all authors. All authors have given approval to the final version of the manuscript.

The authors declare no competing financial interest.

References

To keep the water molecule content, the sample of 100% RH humidity was put into a tightly sealed sample holder. In fact, the reproducibility was confirmed by the data at 295 K after cooling (Figure S4, ).
elements.clean_text:
The manuscript was written through contributions of all authors. All authors have given approval to the final version of the manuscript.

The authors declare no competing financial interest.

References

To keep the water molecule content, the sample of 100% RH humidity was put into a tightly sealed sample holder. In fact, the reproducibility was confirmed by the data at 295 K after cooling (Figure S4, ).

cln_elements.content: The target compound was prepared by the reaction of an aqueous solution of K4[NbIV(CN)8]·2H2O (0.1 mmol, 3.3 mmol dm–3) with a mixed aqueous solution of MnIICl2·4H2O (0.2 mmol, 6.7 mmol dm–3) and 4-aminopyridine (4 mmol, 130 mmol dm–3) using a slow diffusion method. Yellow crystals were obtained by filtering and washing with water. Elemental analyses confirmed that the formula of the obtained compound was Mn3[Nb(CN)8]2(4-aminopyridine)10(4-aminopyridinium)2·12H2O. Calculated: Mn, 7.8; Nb, 8.8; C, 43.2; H, 4.7; N, 26.5%. Found: Mn, 7.7; Nb, 8.7; C, 42.7; H, 4.7; N, 26.4%. The infrared (IR) spectrum showed CN stretching peaks at 2144, 2133, 2120, and 2114 cm–1.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Synthesis

The target compound was prepared by the reaction of an aqueous solution of K4[NbIV(CN)8]⋅2H2O (0.1 mmol, 3.3 mmol dm-3) with a mixed aqueous solution of MnIICl2⋅4H2O (0.2 mmol, 6.7 mmol dm-3) and 4-aminopyridine (4 mmol, 130 mmol dm-3) using a slow diffusion method. Yellow crystals were obtained by filtering and washing with water. Elemental analyses confirmed that the formula of the obtained compound was Mn3[Nb(CN)8]2(4-aminopyridine)10(4-aminopyridinium)2⋅12H2O. Calculated: Mn, 7.8; Nb, 8.8; C, 43.2; H, 4.7; N, 26.5%. Found: Mn, 7.7; Nb, 8.7; C, 42.7; H, 4.7; N, 26.4%. The infrared (IR) spectrum showed CN stretching peaks at 2144, 2133, 2120, and 2114 cm-1.

other properties: IR spectrum CN stretching peaks at 2144, 2133, 2120, and 2114 cm-1

cln_elements.content: Crystal structure of MnII 3[NbIV(CN)8]2(4-aminopyridine)10(4-aminopyridinium)2·12H2O. (a) Coordination environment of Mn and Nb sites. Pyridyl nitrogen atom of noncoordinated 4-aminopyridine is protonated (4-NH2pyH+). (b) Crystal structure viewed along the b axis. Mn–NC–Nb moiety forms a 2D layered structure, and 4-NH2pyH+ is located inside the layer. (c) View of the layer structure. Red, green, gray, cyan, light blue, and blue balls represent Mn, Nb, C, pyridinium N, other N, and O atoms, respectively. Ligand water molecules and zeolitic water molecules are represented as O(L) and O(Z), respectively. H atoms are omitted for clarity.

Pyridyl nitrogen atom of noncoordinated 4-aminopyridine is protonated (4-NH2pyH+). (b) Crystal structure viewed along the b axis. Mn-NC-Nb moiety forms a 2D layered structure, and 4-NH2pyH+ is located inside the layer. (c) View of the layer structure. Red, green, gray, cyan, light blue, and blue balls represent Mn, Nb, C, pyridinium N, other N, and O atoms, respectively. Ligand water molecules and zeolitic water molecules are represented as O(L) and O(Z), respectively. H atoms are omitted for clarity.

metadata.title:
Super-Ionic Conductive Magnet Based on a Cyano-Bridged
Mn–Nb Bimetal Assembly
